items.content_html: One thing I always wondered about game development: in order to make the game (and test the game) wouldn‚Äòt the game developer need to be the best player for the game as well? I mean, how do you make a super hard game without being able to play through and best the most difficult parts? Or come up with the hardest puzzles? Meaning game developers would need to be the best gamers as well?
items.content_text: One thing I always wondered about game development: in order to make the game (and test the game) wouldn‚Äòt the game developer need to be the best player for the game as well? items.title: Goulash Vienna Style
items.content_html:
I am uncertain if I ever posted this, but I just found this write-up of one of my favourite recipes. It always reminds me of home.

Serves 4

Takes at least 3 hours, better more

Ingredients:

  • 1¬†kg beef
  • 800g onions
  • 4 cloves garlic
  • 1 teaspoon caraway
  • 1 tablespoon marjoram
  • 4 tablespoon paprika powder
  • 1 tablespoon (white wine) vinegar
  • Salt
  • Pepper
  • 1 teaspoon tomato paste
  • lard or sunflower seed oil
  • broth

Directions

  • Dice the onions into rough cubes.
  • Dice the beef into 2-4¬†cm cubes
  • Heat the lard/oil and fry the onions slowly to a dark brown. Don‚Äôt burn them!
  • Pur√©e the onions with a mixer or immersion blender
  • Add the cut up garlic, caraway, marjoram, paprika, and vinegar and mix well
  • add a bit of water and let it simmer for 1,5h to let the flavours develop
  • After the 1,5h is up, add the meat and fill with water or broth. The amount is a bit to taste. The meat should still be visible and not swim in water. Add too much and the sauce gets too thin, add too little and you can always thin it later.
  • Simmer for 3 hours or more on low heat. The longer, the better. In the end, you should have a nice deep red colour and a layer of fat swimming on the top.
  • Stir everything to mix in the fat.
  • Season with salt and pepper.

Best prepared the day before. Or even two days before. It gets better with every re-heating.

Eat with baguette, pasta or sp√§tzle. Some heathens eat it with rice.

ü•ò
items.content_text:
I am uncertain if I ever posted this, but I just found this write-up of one of my favourite recipes. It always reminds me of home.

![](https://img.chefkoch-cdn.de/ck.de/rezepte/88/88095/442391-960x720-wiener-saftgulasch-wie-ich-es-mache.jpg)

Serves 4

Takes at least 3 hours, better more

## Ingredients: 
* 1¬†kg beef 
* 800g onions
* 4 cloves garlic
* 1 teaspoon caraway
* 1 tablespoon marjoram
* 4 tablespoon paprika powder
* 1 tablespoon (white wine) vinegar
* Salt
* Pepper
* 1 teaspoon tomato paste
* lard or sunflower seed oil
* broth

## Directions
* Dice the onions into rough cubes.
* Dice the beef into 2-4¬†cm cubes
* Heat the lard/oil and fry the onions slowly to a dark brown. Don‚Äôt burn them!
* Pur√©e the onions with a mixer or immersion blender 
* Add the cut up garlic, caraway, marjoram, paprika, and vinegar and mix well
* add a bit of water and let it simmer for 1,5h to let the flavours develop
* After the 1,5h is up, add the meat and fill with water or broth. The amount is a bit to taste. The meat should still be visible and not swim in water. Add too much and the sauce gets too thin, add too little and you can always thin it later.
* Simmer for 3 hours or more on low heat. The longer, the better. In the end, you should have a nice deep red colour and a layer of fat swimming on the top.
* Stir everything to mix in the fat.
* Season with salt and pepper.

Best prepared the day before. Or even two days before. It gets better with every re-heating.

Eat with baguette, pasta or sp√§tzle. Some heathens eat it with rice.

ü•ò

items.content_html: I finally managed to get babylondreams.de up and running again. I replaced the old Kirby CMS site with a simple HTML based version. My Kirby version was too old to run under modern PHP and upgrading Kirby to a more recent version did my head in. So no more Kirby and all HTML. At least I can edit that directly if I need to.

My Kirby version was too old to run under modern PHP and upgrading Kirby to a more recent version did my head in. So no more Kirby and all HTML. At least I can edit that directly if I need to.

items.content_html: After years of online hiatus I have decided to make Micro.Blog my main site. Of course, it is not as simple as it sounds. For example, none of my already existsing posts show on the homepage (https://alexkucera.micro.blog). Also I have issues with pointing my domain (alexanderkucera.com) to my Micro.blog page. But I am slowly chipping away at my issues. I am sure I will prevail. Eventually‚Ä¶

items.content_html: Yesterday I came across one of the most German things I have seen in a long time. Apparently there is such a thing as an “ArbeitsschutzgetraÃànk”, which means “worker protection drink”. In essence it is an isotonic drink for workers in high heat work places. But I find it hilarious that we Germans felt the need to come up with a convoluted word for it.
items.content_text:
----

Yesterday I came across one of the most German things I have seen in a long time. Apparently there is such a thing as an "ArbeitsschutzgetraÃànk", which means "worker protection drink". In essence it is an isotonic drink for workers in high heat work places. But I find it hilarious that we Germans felt the need to come up with a convoluted word for it.

items.title: 5 - Prepping the vrscene GUI Intro Video
items.content_html:
Text: Recording while waiting for 3D scenes to load. Creating an intro video for an application is so not my thing‚Ä¶

Episode 5 Audio

Duration: 3:00
items.content_text:

Neat. A new Screenflow version. And it has some nice new features. But wow. The full price these days is double (or even more?) then what I paid for it a couple of versions back. But the upgrade price is perfectly fair.

items.content_html: Nailed my Git workflow. Now any changes on the site such as Micropub posts or quick HTML/CSS fixes will find their way back to the Git repo and also any changes from the repo from my desktop or iOS will get published to the site. Awesome.
items.content_text:
----

Nailed my Git workflow. Now any changes on the site such as Micropub posts or quick HTML/CSS fixes will find their way back to the Git repo and also any changes from the repo from my desktop or iOS will get published to the site. Awesome.

items.content_html: Triggering a Git commit from the server works. iOS workflow still on hold because of a bug. And desktop triggering almost there. This was easier then expected.

Triggering a Git commit from the server works. iOS workflow still on hold because of a bug. And desktop triggering almost there. This was easier then expected.
